Also, I just came out on Facebook. So #feelingstressedbutrelieved Dear Childhood,
You were cringy and very awkward but I grew from you. I figured out who I am. I wish I could change somethings about my childhood, but I grew from those experiences too. So hello adulthood I can't wait to live my life. Liked on YouTube: I'm Gay - Eugene Lee Yang https://t.co/dGtyfyFnMr We discussed ignorance in Davis County.

I want everyone in Davis County to know that they need to learn to love. Your negative impact/ignorance can be destructive. Learn love. Right before I left while we were discussing mission questions I asked (I already knew) about what happens when someone has same-sex attraction and wants to go on their mission.

I told my mom about what happened. My mom calmly comforted me. I know that she had my back. When I went to bed that night, I cried. I prayed to feel comfortable and I was comforted. I wanted to ask my leader if I could call my mom (we didn't have phones) and leave early. I didn't and stuck it out as I did in seminary.

The next day I had to leave early for work. When he asked if it was offensive I said it was, other people agreed with me thankfully. I couldn't stand up for myself there because of such homophobia. Other words were thrown, "that's gay", "dude, you're gay" and stuff like that. That didn't bother me like that extreme word. While playing cards with some people at a camp in my dorm room there was this kinda cute boy with a southern drawl who I was kinda crushing on. Within the first 2 minutes of our conversation, he said (thankfully not directly to me) the most offensive word to the gay community. I told him how I felt and he was my biggest supporter outside of the theatre community and my parents. He protected me from small homophobia.

But those scars that started to heal reopened this last Thursday night. I was scared about how things would go, but they went so well. I cried from feeling the spirit so strong. The things the people said in that class changed my heart and made me understand that God loved me more than I could imagine. I loved that class and that teacher. Then the second semester rolled around and I was thankful to get out of that seminary teachers class, at first I was terrified of this new teacher because of some things he had said during some summer seminary lessons. A few weeks later we had a lesson about LGBTQ+ matters. But I did because my parents didn't know I was gay at the time and wouldn't understand why seminary was hard. I become cold and unfeeling towards seminary and stopped caring at all, but still put on the persona of the "perfect Mormon boy" His words hurt my closeted soul and I felt hopeless and depressed. While he was teaching I had one of my friends from high school on the other end of a Snapchat message telling me I was loved and that I should leave the room. I didn't. I was scared. I didn't want to ever go back. I had a seminary teacher the first semester of my senior year who in one lesson was uneducated and said that Tom Christofferson was helped out of his gay relationship, which is false. He said that gay people can't be good parents, which is also false. I know that God loves me. I've gone through something similar earlier this year and made it out the other side, but not with some scars. And these experiences opened up those scars. Now that I'm out, I want to share what happened earlier and what we can learn. At that mission camp, I heard words said about all different types of people that should and hopefully, would never be said to people like that. Nobody there knew I was gay, and I hope that they wouldn't say what they said if they knew. I wanted to say that I was but couldn't. But parents need to teach their kids about love. As Gordon B. Hinckley said (this is paraphrased from what @tanfrance said in his SLC Book Tour): Christ said to love one another, not judging them based on who they are. Christ taught the sinner. They have no control over who chooses to live here. But what needs to happen is education. Parents already teach their kids how to act and behave and sometimes they forget that, but they are told by other adults (teachers, church leaders, older friends, etc.) It was that many of the kids were ignorant. Now I don't blame them. I blame the community that Davis County, Utah is. Because I live in "Wonderbread Utah" I know only a few out gay kids and less than 10 ethnic people. Now I don't blame the county for not having more diversity. This last Wednesday through Friday I had the wonderful experience of going to a missionary camp with my stake. It was a wonderfully powerful experience, but I want to reflect on something that wasn't right. It wasn't that the kids trashed the dorm rooms or staying out too late.
